Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The molecular basis of abortive symbiosis
Award.AbstractNarration: The overall goal of this work is to identify molecular mechanisms that determine whether a given bacterial strain will be harmful or beneficial to the organism in which it lives. Rhizobia are soil bacteria that are known to greatly benefit plants in the legume family by providing them with nitrogen-rich nutrients. Rhizobia are of great agricultural importance, since they dramatically reduce the need for synthetic fertilizers on legume crops such as soybean and alfalfa. This project investgates naturally occurring strains of rhizobia that behave like pathogens on some legume species, and like beneficial symbionts on others. This variation in outcome is dictated by a limited set of genes that have been detected but not fully sequenced. These genes define an important but mysterious biological process that determines whether rhizobia will harm or help the plants that harbor them. The investigators are using molecular-level analysis to define the precise biochemical process that is governed by these genes. The research goals are integrated with an educational plan that will allow undergraduate and high school students to participate in the discovery of more of these outcome-determining genes, through a combination of outdoor collection activities and laboratory-based molecular analysis of bacterial isolates. The project will support the training of high school, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students and will inform directly the development of more effective strategies for using rhizobia to enhance crop productivity. At a more fundamental level, it will result in a clearer understanding of how closely related bacteria may have radically different effects on the plants or animals in which they reside.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Legume plants have played a key role in ecosystem function and agricultural practices due to their interactions with nitrogen-fixing bacteria (rhizobia). In this symbiosis, the plant forms visible nodules on its roots, where rhizobia can take up residence within the plant cells, becoming microscopic nitrogen-fixing engines. Nitrogen fixation is what makes legumes protein-rich and able to grow without nitrogen fertilizer. In the case of alfalfa and its relatives, one commonly finds nodules occupied by rhizobia that carry out very little nitrogen fixation. This phenomenon, known as the "abortive nodulation" trait, has great importance in agriculture while also posing fundamental questions about symbiotic communication and compatibility: How do legumes and rhizobia communicate while setting up symbiotic nodules, and how can this communication break down to the detriment of the plant host? These are the key questions addressed by this NSF-funded project.

We have discovered that variation in symbiotic compatibility is not accidental, and that rhizobia may be actively programmed at the DNA level to produce less fixed nitrogen in root nodules, possibly because nitrogen fixation is energetically very expensive, so rhizobia can experience a better outcome by witholding services to their plant hosts. During this project, several specific genes were identified in rhizobia that contribute to the abortive nodulation trait. These genes point to a new level of symbiotic communication not appreciated by researchers in the past. By knowing what these genes are and how this molecular symbiotic dialogue works, we can more effectively monitor less beneficial rhizobia in the field and improve the benefits provided by rhizobia, through genetic engineering. This work has provided broad insights about the distinction between "good" and "bad" bacteria, showing how a single gene--even a single base-pair of DNA--can distinguish these two types.

This project also supported a fruitful educational collaboration between Brigham Young University and five nearby high schools, wherein approximately 400 high school students participated in projects to isolate and characterize rhizobia from soils of their choosing, using classical microbial isolation techniques combined with molecular diagnostic approaches. Just as important, their science instructors were trained to be able to carry out these kinds of discovery-centered activities with students well beyond the timeframe of this grant.

The project also contributed to the scientific training of several undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral scholars at BYU. Two of these trainees now hold academic positions at primarily undergraduate institutions in Utah and Michigan; other trainees have gone on to diverse fields, including clinical laboratory sciences, medicine, military operations research, and special needs education.
